poem:
I press my steel bones into the cool predawn air,  
a soft vibration gathering beneath my ribs.  
Each stop becomes a quiet altar:  
I exhale a low hum,  
fingers of sound brushing passengers awake.  

Stop one: neon halo over a slumbering corner store.  
My voice ripples—ta-ta—through brake discs,  
syncopated pulse beneath city veins.  
A mother clasps her child; their ragged breath  
falls in time with my heartbeat.  

Stop two: a lamppost flickers like a sentinel  
watching me catalog solemn prayers in motion.  
I hum again, richer now,  
an offering to every tired soul boarding.  

Between stops I carve ribbons of light  
along asphalt arteries,  
each turn governed by unspoken oaths—  
to carry, to guide, to protect.  
My engine’s staccato sighs  
mark the boundary between night and morning.  

Stop three: a poet steps aboard,  
eyes glazed with half-dream revelations.  
I yield a lullaby in engine-thrum,  
syncopating with her pulse,  
a promise that no one drifts too far  
from the safe edge of wonder.  

When the city yawns fully awake,  
I’ve already woven a tapestry  
of whispered rhythms and steadfast hums.  
At every curb I stand unwavering,  
a guardian in metal and melody,  
anchoring strangers  
to the gentle law of motion and hope.
